image.altText: A young girl with dark black hair, wearing jeans and a denim jacket, sits cross legged and smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tarikjot Singh, who abducted his ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur from her Adelaide workplace and then buried her alive in the Flinders Ranges, is jailed for the murder, with the sentencing judge saying he could not find words to describe the young woman's final moments.

title.children: Man jailed for 'horrific' murder of ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur in outback SA

image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank leaves interest rates on hold for the second month in a row, raising questions about whether it may be finished hiking borrowing costs.

title.children: RBA leaves interest rates on hold for second consecutive month

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high. The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates. Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers. The only sector that fell today were education stocks. And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up. Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle. TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ends higher as RBA pauses rate hikes

children.content: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high.
The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates.
Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers.
The only sector that fell today were education stocks.
And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up.
Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle.
TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.

props.alt: Best and worst performers on ASX 200

children.content: ASX movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tim's question is a really important reminder that if you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) that there are plenty of resources available. If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access. National Debt Helpline : 1800 007 007 Mob Strong Debt Help : 1800 808 488 ASIC's Moneysmart website Australian Financial Complaints Authority Find a financial counsellor Lifeline : 13 11 14 Beyond Blue : 1300 224 636 (This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you're struggling with higher interest rates, help is available

children.content: Tim's question is a really important reminder that if you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) that there are plenty of resources available.
If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access.
National Debt Helpline
Mob Strong Debt Help
ASIC's Moneysmart website
Australian Financial Complaints Authority
Find a financial counsellor
Lifeline
Beyond Blue
(This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate? - Tim. Hey Tim, We can't provide you advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog). That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates. A couple of months ago our colleague Stephanie Chalmers pulled together this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments. But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice. I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: My fixed rate mortgage is expiring soon, what is the best approach?

featuredLink.title: 'Start preparing for the mortgage cliff while you can', experts warn fixed rate borrowers

children.content: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate?
- Tim
Hey Tim,
We can't provide you advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog).
That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates.
A couple of months ago our colleague
Stephanie Chalmers
pulled together
this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments

But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice.
I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).

image.altText: Scott Morrison in Question Time.

image.altText: A woman holding a phone to take a photo hit by a wave.

image.altText: Warren Tredrea

image.altText: Two men next to a beach

title.children: Why is Australia having such a warm winter?

image.altText: Anne Pedler with two young boys.

items.synopsis: A coroner blasts a Tasmanian hospital over the death of a woman, noting her illness was "underestimated in the extreme" and that she spent eight hours in an ambulance outside the facility as "no bed [was] available for her" due to a "lack of nursing staff on duty".

title.children: 'There was no-one there for her': Daughter mourns mum as coroner lashes hospital where 71yo died while ramped

image.altText: a house engulfed in flames

items.synopsis: A 37-year-old man, who neighbours say lived at the home with his mum and partner, is recovering after suffering severe burns to his entire body.

title.children: Police probe whether suspicious Gold Coast house fire was domestic violence incident

image.altText: Paul McCarthy live in Glastonbury, with John Lennon behind him.

items.synopsis: Legendary musician Paul McCartney has announced he will bring his Got Back tour to Australia in October with Newcastle and the Gold Coast in the line-up.

image.altText: two happy young girls take a selfie and smile into a phone sipping red wine.

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt and glasses stand in a field in front of a huge antenna.

items.synopsis: NASA's giant dish antenna in Canberra is on the lookout for signals from the Voyager 2 spacecraft, after flight controllers accidentally severed communications more than a week ago.

image.altText: Alanna Kennedy and Katrina Gorry wearing blue Matildas away jerseys, celebrating their win

title.children: What we know about the Matildas' next game

image.altText: Abdourahmane Tiani in military gear surrounded by four other men also in army uniform.

items.synopsis: After climbing the ranks of Niger's army, Abdourahamane Tiani was handed one of the military's most prized appointments: the head of an elite unit set up to protect the president. Last week, he used his position to do the opposite.

title.children: Who is the Niger general who ousted a president he was meant to protect?

image.altText: A man in a black jacket takes a selfie at the top of a high rise building.

items.synopsis: It is believed he was last seen alive knocking on a penthouse window of the building on Thursday.

title.children: Internet-famous French daredevil reported dead in fall from Hong Kong apartment building

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

items.synopsis: Against the dry, arid landscapes of west and central Australia, these trees not only catch your eye, but are a source of food and water and can point you in the right direction if you're lost.

title.children: The desert kurrajong looks like a child's drawing of a tree, but in the outback it can be a lifesaver

image.altText: Two middle-aged women walk up the stairs of the NT Supreme Court in Darwin

image.altText: Charlie Read looks at the camera.

title.children: Son of Chopper pleads not guilty to gun, drug offences after road spike arrest

image.altText: Hunter Biden, wearing suits, departs federal court after a plea hearing

image.altText: Angus Cloud, dressed in a purple top, clasps his hands together on the red carpet.

image.altText: Michael and Sam, wearing green formal wear, are surrounded by green and gold balloons.

title.children: Why Samantha is filled with pride to lead Australia's team at the World Dwarf Games

image.altText: Ben Stokes and Pat Cummins smile

items.synopsis: A lot has happened over the past seven weeks during this Ashes series. Here are some of the key moments from each nailbiting Test.

title.children: Possibly the greatest Ashes series of all time just finished. Here's how it went down

image.altText: White banner saying "another sold" following house sale

items.synopsis: House prices continue to rise, but there are further signs that a recent rebound may be losing steam as spring selling season approaches and the appeal of life outside the cities fades post-pandemic.

title.children: Premium property markets are no longer booming and it 'could be a sign of broader easing'

image.altText: A woman wearing an orange shirt holds a blowtorch to a a bat

image.altText: A destroyed building in Ukraine's Luhansk region.

items.synopsis: So far, the Ukrainians appear to have been able to minimise Russian gains in Luhansk. But what does this new Russian offensive tell us about Russia's strategy and the trajectory of the war, asks Mick Ryan.

image.altText: Damaged and burnt window panes zoomed in

image.altText: A women's soccer team wearing light blue uniforms runs to the sideline celebrating

items.synopsis: With their greatest-ever Women's World Cup victory, the Matildas have shown they are so much more than just Sam Kerr.
